bestBHT.bht: The false witness against Stephen distorted his words, taking them out of context and misrepresenting what he had actually said, just like what had happened with Jesus. They falsely accused Stephen of continually speaking against the Temple and the law, charging him with blasphemy. By doing this, they aimed to incite the people against him and create immense anger. However, there are reasons to believe that the entire testimony was false and that Stephen never actually made those statements.

Henry Alford: The falsehood of their witness consisted, as in the similar case of our Lord, in taking Stephen’s words out of their context, and misrepresenting what perhaps in so many words he had actually said.
this holy place] The temple: see Matt. xxiv. 15; ch. xxi. 28.
Albert Barnes: If they did report merely his 'words'; if Stephen had actually said what they affirmed, yet they perverted his meaning.
It is altogether improbable that he ever did, for the following reasons.
The probability therefore is, that the whole testimony was 'false,' and was artfully invented to produce the utmost exasperation among the people.
Philip Schaff: These witnesses, even perhaps quoting before the Sanhedrim the very words used by the eloquent Nazarene teacher, took them out of their original context, distorted them, and evidently represented him as unceasingly assailing the Temple and the holy Jewish rites."
When they wanted to excite the populace against Stephen, they did not scruple to charge him with the most awful blasphemy against Moses and even against the God of Israel.
His offense was, he had spoken against the Temple and the law.
Archibald T. Robertson: False witnesses. Just as Caiaphas did with Jesus.
Ceaseth not. Wild charge just like a false witness.
Stephen talks in the synagogues against the law and the holy temple.
John Gill: Stephen was continually telling the people, that in a little time their temple would be destroyed, and an end be put to temple worship, and to all the rituals and ceremonies of the law of Moses.
Speaking against the temple and the law was sufficient to make good a charge of blasphemy.
Stephen, who was now before the council, at whom they pointed, and whose name, through contempt, they would not mention.

bhtAttempts.bht: The false witness against Stephen took his words out of context and misrepresented what he had actually said, just like the case of Jesus. These witnesses distorted Stephen's words to make it seem like he was constantly speaking against the Temple and the law, which would be sufficient to charge him with blasphemy. It is even said that they charged him with the most awful blasphemy against Moses and the God of Israel. Their intention was clear: to excite the people against Stephen and create the utmost exasperation among them. However, the probability is that the entire testimony was false, as there are reasons to believe that Stephen never actually said what they claimed.

However, there are reasons to believe that the entire testimony was false and that Stephen never actually made those statements.

The false witness against Stephen distorted his words, misrepresenting what he had actually said. They falsely accused Stephen of continually speaking against the Temple and the law, charging him with blasphemy. By doing this, they aimed to incite the people against him and create immense anger. However, Stephen's words were likely taken out of context and the entire testimony against him may have been fabricated, as there are reasons to believe that he never actually made those statements.
